column2:
@tenaciouslibbs Agree! But not sure that's a good thing.

AC had a super hardcore niche fanbase but never really made sense to most people.

It feels like Starcruiser will follow the same path, with dwindling returns as the niche dries up.

AC was $25 for PI + $6 for a Kungaloosh. Not $6K.

He also did something brilliant here that even Disney‚Äôs own marketing didn‚Äôt achieve‚Ä¶

He wrote the high price of the Starcruiser experience into the story. Scoffing at, like the rest of us. But giving us story motivation to say ‚ÄúFine. I‚Äôll pay. I have no choice. It‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù

Mike Celestino has embodied an original character for his upcoming Galactic Starcruiser voyage¬†and shot a short film to introduce his story.

This is amazing ‚Äì¬†and makes him the geekiest person I know. Which is awesome.

@laughing_place @WhosTheBosskPod

https://t.co/Ez90IODi3x

Experiences are the future of entertainment. People want to interact and engage, not just sit and watch. But they want to do it on their own terms, not because they were told to.

Organic engagement is the ultimate sign of a successful experience.

And it's so fun when it works.

It's so much more fun to have that community and discussion surrounding each new nugget of info than it is to just have it all dumped at once.

The bigger experience surrounding the entertainment is rapidly rising to be better than the entertainment itself, for the biggest fans.

Naturally, this is only true of the niche / hardcore audience.

It's this audience that craves more. To not just get excited about SEEING a world of fiction, but to actually feel like they are part of it.

The trickle of movie marketing feels like the story is told in realtime.

This is fascinating.

My take: Watching movies is a passive activity. The marketing process is active engagement.

It's become more fun to interact with the experience of marketing than it is to see the final product being promoted.

Marketing IS the product. https://t.co/EmIlogovzD
@KJKnies Thanks. Maybe I can find a used one!
@rheinwaldjones Interesting! Will look into that more. Thanks!
Sigh. Flood of bots again. I should have learned from last time. DMs are now off. Just @ me.

Themed entertainment illustrator friends - We are in need of a good concept artist to knock out a few sketches.

DM me your rates and portfolio!
@tomcat335 ...better!

@rheinwaldjones These are great thoughts. The challenge is that I want to keep the high resolution for modern gaming. The A1U displays are capable of 1280x960 HD resolution, so RCA won't cut it, as that'll push it down to SD.

I know ‚Äì¬†it's an annoying, dumb challenge.

@rheinwaldjones Really geeky. I've modded my Arcade1Up machine to my Xbox One and Nintendo Switch so I can play console exclusives on the arcade cab. But aside from classic ports, modern 16:9 games don't offer a 4:3 letterbox setting for use on classic displays. It just squishes it.
@tomcat335 That seems like what I'm looking for... but wow pricey. This is just for a hobby project. That device alone would be worth more than the whole project. :)

Anyone know of a device that can letterbox an HDMI signal? That is, take in a 16:9 HD signal and convert it to 4:3 letterboxed?

...or a hacky way to accomplish this if a single device doesn't exist?

Trying to make 16:9 content retain the correct aspect ratio on a 4:3 display.
@WhosTheBosskPod Did you witness the destruction of the Razor Crest as a young child?
@RobyMB @GoAwayGreen @WaltsFrzenHead @heybrucewright @n8creative @Make_It_Cool Pretty sure ‚ÄúChamber of‚Äù anything is automatically cool.

@funkpwer @JennyENicholson Yep, inevitably this WILL spawn strategy groups online, sharing every choice they made to optimize an ideal ‚Äútouring plan‚Äù to see all the best scenes and have the best interactions.

Those that don‚Äôt know those tricks will be shut out of any capacity-limited moments.

It‚Äôs pretty incredible to see immersive concepts I‚Äôve loved - and even helped create in our own small scale productions - get such such widespread attention and praise.

A whole new world of immersive entertainment is here - and it‚Äôs only going to get bigger and more exciting. https://t.co/JsrliS7OCB

@WaltsFrzenHead @heybrucewright @GoAwayGreen @n8creative @Make_It_Cool Yeah, I don't like puzzles either. I love the themed environments, story, effects, and interactions of escape rooms... but just wish the puzzles didn't exist.

And hardcore escape roomers are INTENSE. I can't compete. I just stand in a corner and watch the madness ensue.
@heybrucewright @GoAwayGreen @n8creative @Make_It_Cool ...though there is definitely a market for immersive horror bondage dungeons too.
@ExpThemePark Long term contracts with regular hours and guaranteed performances are gold for actors.
@GoAwayGreen @n8creative @Make_It_Cool So what made you finally do one?

@GoAwayGreen @bioreconstruct We've been producing immersive theatrical experiences in Orlando that are structurally similar to Galactic Starcruiser since 2015. But it takes the power of Disney/Star Wars to popularize the format.

(Some of Starcruiser's Imagineers did attend our productions...)

@GoAwayGreen @bioreconstruct Disney is fantastic at watching the landscape of entertainment, hospitality, and retail, then picking out the elements that are intriguing and putting their incredible resources behind it, transforming it.

@AliBeemerPR I think once GMA shared their early exclusive (8:48am), it may have prompted some others to post early too.

Overall it's great to see trust placed in the hands of online outlets¬†‚Äì and even influencers ‚Äì when in the past they would never have been trusted with embargoed coverage.

@AliBeemerPR Assuming you're talking about pew pew space stuff, I saw a couple outlets jump the 9am gun by a few minutes this morning. And a handful of minor videos yesterday and overnight on one YouTube channel.

Otherwise, pretty rock solid. I'm impressed.

Alright, concluding the flood of Galactic Starcruiser spoilers & thoughts with a beautiful piece by @BrookeGMcDonald about how strongly immersive experiences can emotionally impact people, bringing them closer together.

That's what it's really all about!

https://t.co/qUoffhJPMU

I do hope this experience doesn't just get handed off to ops to simplify and optimize for efficiency.

But instead, I hope it's a playground for WDI to keep evolving and improving.

Again, a link to her excellent review of the experience ‚Äì a totally fair look at what's great and what sounds like still isn't quite ready for primetime:

https://t.co/hVyCRdBcDg

"I am not made of money and for that price, I hope for and expect near perfection."

Another gem from @amy_geek.

Amidst all the coverage today, this is exactly what's holding me back from booking Galactic Starcruiser.

I'll hold off for v2.0, when all the bugs are worked out.

"The schedule overflows so much that the finale even cut into my dinner on the last night."

Seems to be a common thread among most Galactic Starcruiser visitors ‚Äì¬†TOO much going on. I'd hate if I had to choose between a story moment and a meal.

https://t.co/hVyCRdBcDg

@rheinwaldjones I agree with that mentality, but you never know what people like and don't like. Even if there are no "lesser" tracks, it opens the door to reactions like "aw, I wish I had seen that" or "that sounds more fun than what I did."

At $6K, those feelings are much harder to swallow.

@AliciaStella Kinda the sad reality here is that everything that was meant to be in Galaxy's Edge for everyone to enjoy is now put behind a massive pay wall.

I get it. But I don't like it.

@ThemePkConcepts A great point. In @attractions' write-up, they noted there was one major "wow" element that one person in their group got to see while others didn't, and that was disappointing.

For multiple visits, that's fun. But for $6K? I'd better get to see ALL the good stuff in one go.

As Sleep No More famously puts it:
"Fortune favors the bold."

I really do hope that Galactic Starcruiser enables mainstream tourists to see the value in actively participating in an experience, not just letting it be spoon-fed to them.

Some are quick to say "eh, that feels like work."

And that's fine. There are plenty of relaxing vacations for those who want to lie by the pool, have some drinks, sleep a lot, or stare at the stars.

But those who crave adventure¬†‚Äì this is the call.

This notion of "you only get out what you put in" has been at the core of immersive theatrical experiences since Sleep No More debuted in 2009¬†‚Äì¬†13 years ago!

The masses have yet to fully embrace this notion that the most engaging entertainment requires a little bit of effort.

"Passengers get back what they put into their time aboard the Halcyon. If you suspend your disbelief, embrace the story and participate without self-consciousness, this will be a trip you, and your family, will never forget."

Great piece by @sarahwhit10.

https://t.co/wJE5ok5hOm

That's exactly what this is ‚Äì bringing the excitement and spirit of adventure of the Star Wars universe to those of us who aren't Jedi... but wish we could be.

That feeling is what you're paying thousands for, it seems.

Much like a theme park ride ‚Äì¬†you can know everything that's going to happen and still have an awesome time, every time.

The irony, of course, is: https://t.co/N2fIADm9nl

This seemingly isn't about surprises. Mysteries to unravel. Secret passages. Exploration, discovery. Awe-inspiration visuals. So many things that make something like Meow Wolf tick.

Nah ‚Äì this is about living in the world of Star Wars. Or, at least Disney's version of it.

There's not a whole lot of mystery. There really isn't anything being shown off today that we didn't know about already. A few more details here and there of how it all plays out.

So knowing all that in advance, what's left?

The actual adventure of it all. Living it.

What's fascinating me right now about Galactic Starcruiser...

It's really hard to distill the excitement of this experience into some photos, videos, and write-ups online.

It's like we've seen it all and there are no surprises.

Because it's about the EXPERIENCE of being there.

This is phenomenal. I want this in my house.

Literally should be a partnership with @Amazon. https://t.co/2pT9o5ccXt

So interesting to see different sides of all this.

Some say the story is fulfilling, character interactions are incredible, and the whole experience is mind-blowing.

While others say... eh, STILL doesn't quite get there, despite all the years of marketing hype. https://t.co/o3goHqS8er

Even Disney's years-in-the-making Story Engine technology seems to be stumbling, at least somewhat, at delivering the "perfect" personalized adventure for every guest.

But I still love the design and the intent. Can't wait to see this grow stronger over time.

Branching stories with multiple concurrent story paths is HARD to execute and make everyone happy, without spelling out the whole story in advance.

It's like people need to know what they're getting into before they actually do it, somehow without spoiling it.

Results were similar ‚Äì¬†some guests LOVED their stories and came back as many as 10 times to experience all the branches. They could because the price was only ~$45 per visit.

But other guests started on a path that didn't resonate with them and never came back.

We've created multiple immersive theatrical productions with branching narratives and have seen the triumphs and perils of this first-hand.

When Shadows Fall (in Orlando, 2016) had 12 different tracks that could be chosen from a tablet, a simpler version of this data pad.

Video games let you go back & play different levels and branches multiple times, with no extra cost. You don't have constant FOMO because you can easily just do it again.

In immersive theatrical experiences, I'm always bitter when I end up on a "lesser" track without knowing it.

Absolutely the #1 challenge of IRL immersive branching narratives ‚Äì¬†not all choices are good ones for everyone. 

You can end up with a path you just don't like, leaving you wondering if you would have preferred a different track.

Tough when you have to pay $6K to "play" again. https://t.co/UlVI128EwA
^ an excerpt from the excellent Galactic Starcruiser review from @Attractions, well worth a read ‚Äì¬†https://t.co/K3KhDH7ZBB

When Disney lets guests role play:

"We also saw a couple get engaged in the atrium. [‚Ä¶] The woman told me they weren‚Äôt sure if they would be allowed to marry. [‚Ä¶] I asked if it was because they were different species. She said no, it‚Äôs because he‚Äôs her brother."

üëÄ üòÇ https://t.co/eqGj7tpblQ

@PatrickSKling It's kinda brutal when the local news comes in and blasts everything with their super bright lights, tacking on their surface-level commentary.

That kind of coverage can make ANYTHING look silly.

"If you ever were in a college improv group [‚Ä¶] Galactic Starcruiser will let you use those skills and then some. On the other hand, if the idea of being asked to play along in such a way fills with you with dread, well, this probably isn‚Äôt for you."

https://t.co/98BEFwRXy7

Cruise activities on land / "in space"? Yep.

Star Wars? Hmm...?

Not my thing, but they seem to be enjoying it. (Also, local TV news bits are always a little staged and cheesy.) https://t.co/laJpk7uDrF

My favorite line:

"[If you're] willing to set aside any cynicism and too-cool-for-school posturing and embrace the spirit of the whole thing¬†‚Äì you‚Äôre likely to have a good time‚Ä¶ if you can afford it."

An incredibly fair and balanced, review of Galactic Starcruiser from @grmartin.

The good, the bad, and everything in between. Well worth a read ‚Äì¬†and mostly spoiler-free. https://t.co/oYbzP4DebZ

Massive congratulations to the Galactic Starcruiser team for launching this project, YEARS in the making.

From blue sky to Legends of Frontierland to the stars, bringing immersive character-driven entertainment to the masses is no easy feat.

A huge win for all in this industry. https://t.co/YyL18XvFpt

@RobyMB Neither of those. I‚Äôm super curious about it. But I personally also don‚Äôt want to see too much in case I ever do go!

I stayed mostly spoiler free for 2 years before finally getting on Rise. So glad I did. It was tough though.
@GoAwayGreen I‚Äôm convinced this is @skubersky with more hair and an accent.

Galactic Starcruiser spoiler flood gates opening in 1 hour.

Will you read / watch?

(I‚Äôm still debating how much I want to see, in case I ever go‚Ä¶)
RT @POTUS: I want every member of the LGBTQI+ community ‚Äî especially the kids who will be impacted by this hateful bill ‚Äî to know that you‚Ä¶

This is certainly appalling. The whole of it. The bill itself. The fact that this can even exist or be proposed inn the first place.

And the silence is unreal. https://t.co/KhJc97tPO7

But ultimately it‚Äôs the experience itself that matters.

And I‚Äôve heard from multiple trusted friends that were there this week that absolutely loved it. And that makes me happy.

Universal‚Äôs social media and PR presence, by contrast, feels so real. So genuine. So friendly and warm.

It‚Äôs no wonder their fan base is glowing all the time while Disney‚Äôs gets increasingly bitter.

This is why I‚Äôve specifically been posting about the marketing and PR surrounding the Galactic Starcruiser - not the experience itself.

It feels a bit fumbled in many ways, much like it was for Galaxy‚Äôs Edge.

Too manufactured. Not authentic. We all see through it.

The world of PR is weird. At its best, it‚Äôs delivering inside access that otherwise wouldn‚Äôt be seen.

But at its worst, it‚Äôs manipulative and disingenuous.

And it‚Äôs kinda hard to tell the difference these days.

I have no skin in the game anymore.

But I do still have a very positive impression of most of Disney‚Äôs PR staff. They were genuine and kind and helpful.

Except a select few. Who were ruthless and talked to me like a child. That was never fun.

It‚Äôs not entirely an evil system. It‚Äôs understandable to want to control the media narrative. But it is a flawed approach in today‚Äôs landscape.

Today - we never know what we can trust any online. The assumption is that everything might be faked.

And this just heightens that.

I also fortunately had enough of a large audience that they couldn‚Äôt avoid inviting me for a while, as they knew I‚Äôd just go myself and cover it anyway. They‚Äôd rather try to enable me to have the best story possible, which I always appreciated.

I agree with Len‚Äôs ‚Äúecho chamber‚Äù comment.

While fortunately did cover MANY amazing events and grand unveilings, I became increasingly disheartened over the years as I was encouraged to be a ‚Äúgood media partner.‚Äù

I was scolded many times.

This thread is spot on - and a big reason why I got out of the ‚Äúgame.‚Äù I couldn‚Äôt lie.

I never totally played by their rules, offering fair criticism when it was due.

I was removed from media lists twice & had to set up meetings to work it out. Both were silly misunderstandings https://t.co/d6fMTZJZPV
@smitchhhh What if the website was just always a 10? üò≥

@PatrickSKling I hope all that is true.

So far, only certain ‚Äútypes‚Äù of people have become regulars and superfans of things like this. Alternative people. DnD‚Äôers. Etc.

We call them the ‚Äúcool bunch of weirdos‚Äù - a phrase coined by one of our own superfans.

Disney is so much more mainstream.
RT @franklinleonard: Most of us aren't journalists, obviously, but can we at least try to triple source any "news" that doesn't come from a‚Ä¶
RT @nktpnd: There's about to be a tremendous amount of misinformation and repurposed video footage being passed around. Be extremely judici‚Ä¶

I spent today casually chatting about Star Wars¬†‚Äì which now feels so frivolous in the face of real life war.

This is terrifying and not the time to flippantly debate details of a fictional space war "experience."

I feel for all impacted & just hope it doesn't escalate further.
@strowbridge Cheers to many more immersive adventures, big and small!
@CathodeCoaster Makes me wonder what‚Äôs going to happen once Starcruiser is turned over to ops for a while. Hopefully those performer contracts are tight!

This has been quite the marketing challenge for Disney, juggling innovation with tried-and-true concepts.

It‚Äôs going to be interesting to see what sticks most as the first paid guests get in there.

I am hoping it‚Äôs THIS. Not trivia, card games, or drinking. Immersive adventure!

This. This is what I was waiting to see.

Kudos to @strowbridge, @mtgexp, and Cory Rouse for the innovation baked into the Galactic Starcruiser.

That ‚Äústory engine‚Äù has been in the works for years.

Videos like this get me excited and inspired all over again. https://t.co/ob8MMPZGA0

@Kneon They haven‚Äôt ‚Äúlost‚Äù me.

Just left me a little confused. Still hopeful, but a bit disappointed in what I‚Äôve seen so far.

I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs all lovely. But perhaps just not want I want.

Which is fine. Like I said, feels like I‚Äôm just not the target audience.
No surprises here so far.

Room tour:

https://t.co/DpsSiVvyYU https://t.co/YdhwsXJGQh

Looks like some videos are starting to surface from the outer reaches of space, aboard the @StarWars Galactic Starcruiser.

Singing performance:
https://t.co/cIIFVW2O2f https://t.co/QZv1CLKext
@VirtualElena @janehk These tweets speak to me deeply. Just sent you a DM!
